Hello!

I am a student of Artificial Intelligence, and I have been researching
about it for the last years, after some implementations I am releasing
my last one based on the idea of Genetic Art Tool by Mattias
Fagerlund.

The project website is http://sourceforge.net/projects/jcppn (there
are some generated images on the screenshot section)

Below are some of the main differences on my implementation:
 - Use of HSL color scheme instead of RGB, what gives more natural colors
 - Use of perlin noises as a type of a transfer function instead of
applying it to input coordinates (the transfer functions used are:
sigmoid, gauss, perlin, cosine, inverse and binary)
 - Use of textures as an input map (enabled if there is an image file
named "txt1.png" on the "c:\jccpn\input" folder)

It is just a preview version, I still need to work improving the
usability and add more features to it (I already made it produce 3D
model textures to apply on an avatar skin/clothing)

To run it, use the following command line:
java -Xmx256M -jar jcppn.jar
(It will work if you double click on the jar file, but it will lack
memory while saving images).

Here is a brief overview of the GUI:
 - The numbers on each image is the specie #
 - Use the slider of each image to define its fitness, the checkbox
will mark the organism for elitism, copying it to the next generation
 - Click on an image to open the god mode window
 - The Generate button will evolve the generation
 - The load button will load a previously saved .org file (there are
some files attached to this e-mail)
God Mode:
 - Click on the image to save it do disk (an organism file and a
1024x1024 png image, it will take some time to render it, please wait for
the "Images saved" message box)
 - The weights of the network are shown on the middle pane, and the
connections on the right one.

Known issues:
 - There are some memory leaks while rendering the images, if you get
problems of the image not being saved, close the program and reopen
it. (The organism file will be always saved, so you can restore your
work on the new session).

Regards,
William Monti
